title: Milo Yiannopoulos resigns from alt-right news site Breitbart after comments 'supporting paedophilia' | London Evening Standard
text:
Tuesday 21 February 2017 20:48 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Controversial comments: the writer and public speaker has resigned following outcry Rex 
The senior editor of controversial alt-right news website Breitbart has resigned after sparking outrage with comments appearing to condone paedophilia. 
Milo Yiannopoulos, the site’s Tech editor, has been the centre of multiple rows over his controversial views about women, race and religion. 
And in a video that surfaced last week he appeared to condone sexual relationships between men and boys as young as 13. 
His comments caused a revolt amongst Breitbart’s staff who threatened to resign if Mr Yiannopoulos, 32, was not disciplined. 
On Tuesday Breitbart published an article revealing Mr Yiannopoulos had handed in his resignation and it had been accepted. 
Milo Yiannopoulos : controversial (Jeremy Papasso /Daily Camera via AP) 
A statement from him read: “Breitbart News has stood by me when others caved. They have allowed me to carry conservative and libertarian ideas to communities that would otherwise never have heard them. 
“They have been a significant factor in my success. I’m grateful for that freedom and for the friendships I forged there. 
“I would be wrong to allow my poor choice of words to detract from my colleagues’ important reporting, so today I am resigning from Breitbart, effective immediately. This decision is mine alone.” Milo Yiannopoulos on Steve Bannon in Channel 4 News interview 
He added: “When your friends have done right by you, you do right by them. For me, now, that means stepping aside so my colleagues at Breitbart can get back to the great work they do.” 
Mr Yiannopoulos joined the news company in 2014 under Steve Bannon – the then chairman who went on to be appointed President Trump’s senior advisor. 
His comments on child abuse were made during an interview on podcast site The Drunken Peasants”. Presidential aide: Stephen Bannon hired Milo for Breitbart (REUTERS) 
During the conversation, he joked about a sexual encounter he had with a Catholic priest as a teenager and said: “You’re misunderstanding what pedophilia means. 
“Paedophilia is not a sexual attraction to somebody 13 years old who is sexually mature. Paedophilia is attraction to children who have not reached puberty.” 
He added that consent by minors is “arbitrary and oppressive.” 
He defended his comments in a statement released on his Facebook page over the weekend, writing: “I do not support paedophilia. Period. Milo Yiannopoulos challenged on Breitbart News headlines about Muslims and feminism on Channel 4 News 
“It is a vile and disgusting crime, perhaps the very worst. There are selectively edited videos doing the rounds, as part of a coordinated effort to discredit me from establishment Republicans, that suggest I am soft on the subject. Donald Trump to rip-up Obama's pollution safeguards 
“I’m partly to blame. My own experiences as a victim led me to believe I could say anything I wanted to on this subject, no matter how outrageous. 
“But I understand that my usual blend of British sarcasm, provocation and gallows humour might have come across as flippancy, a lack of care for other victims or, worse, ‘advocacy.’ I deeply regret that.” 
A Breitbart News company statement released after the press conference said: “Milo Yiannopoulos’s bold voice has sparked much-needed debate on important cultural topics confronting universities, the LGBTQ community, the press, and the tech industry. 
“Milo notified us this morning of his decision to resign as editor of Breitbart Tech and we accepted his resignation.” More about:
